title: Run System File Checker
description: Scans the integrity of all protected system files and replaces corrupted files with a cached copy.
ticket_template: Ran SFC scan to check for and repair Windows system file corruption.

execution.step: Open a new Command Prompt or PowerShell terminal as an Administrator.
Run the scan. This may take some time.

notice.content: The scan may take 5-15 minutes. If SFC finds errors it cannot repair, you may need to run the DISM command afterward.

title: Run DISM RestoreHealth Scan
description: Uses Deployment Imaging Service and Management Tool (DISM) to scan and repair the Windows system image.
ticket_template: Ran DISM RestoreHealth to repair corrupted Windows system image files.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt or PowerShell as Administrator.
Run the DISM command to scan and repair the system image. This process may take 10–30 minutes.

notice.content: Use this command when SFC fails to repair corrupted system files. Ensure you're connected to the internet, as DISM may download necessary files from Windows Update.

title: Flush DNS Cache
description: Clears the local DNS resolver cache to help resolve network connectivity issues.
ticket_template: Flushed the DNS resolver cache.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt or PowerShell as an Administrator.
Execute the flush command.

title: Release & Renew IP Address
description: Releases the current IP address and requests a new one from the DHCP server.
ticket_template: Performed an IP release and renew to resolve network configuration issues.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt.
Run the renew command.

title: Run DISM CheckHealth
description: Quickly checks if the Windows image has any corruption and if it can be repaired.
ticket_template: Executed DISM CheckHealth to assess whether the Windows image is corrupted and repairable.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt or PowerShell as Administrator.
Run the DISM CheckHealth command. This is a quick scan and usually finishes in seconds.

title: Run DISM ScanHealth
description: Performs a more thorough scan to determine if the Windows image has any corruption.
ticket_template: Executed DISM ScanHealth to perform an in-depth scan for corruption in the Windows image.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt or PowerShell as Administrator.
Run the DISM ScanHealth command. This may take some time to complete.

title: Enable Built-in Administrator Account
description: Enables the default built-in Administrator account in Windows.
ticket_template: Enabled the built-in Administrator account using the net user command.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt or PowerShell as Administrator.
Run the following command to enable the built-in Administrator account.

title: Disable Built-in Administrator Account
description: Disables the default built-in Administrator account in Windows for security.
ticket_template: Disabled the built-in Administrator account using the net user command.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt or PowerShell as Administrator.
Run the following command to disable the built-in Administrator account.

title: Create New Administrator User (With Password)
description: Creates a new local user and adds it to the Administrators group with a specified password.
ticket_template: Created a new local administrator account with a specified password.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt or PowerShell as Administrator.
Create the new user with a password (replace USERNAME and PASSWORD).
Add the new user to the Administrators group.

title: Create New Administrator User (No Password)
description: Creates a new local administrator account without setting a password.
ticket_template: Created a new local administrator account without a password for temporary access.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt or PowerShell as Administrator.
Create the new user with no password (replace USERNAME).
Add the new user to the Administrators group.

title: Reset Microsoft Edge
description: Resets Microsoft Edge settings to their default state, resolving common browser issues.
ticket_template: Reset Microsoft Edge to default settings to resolve browser-related issues.

execution.step: Open Microsoft Edge.
Click the three dots (⋯) in the top-right corner and select 'Settings'.
In the left menu, go to 'Reset settings'.
Click on 'Restore settings to their default values'.
Click 'Reset' to confirm. This will remove extensions, custom settings, and startup configurations.

title: Inspect Services via MSConfig
description: Opens the System Configuration tool (msconfig) to review and identify non-essential or suspicious services running at startup.
ticket_template: Accessed MSConfig to inspect and evaluate services. Reviewed non-Microsoft and third-party services for potential issues or unnecessary startups.

execution.step: Press `Win + R` to open the Run dialog.
Navigate to the 'Services' tab.
Check the box for 'Hide all Microsoft services' to view only third-party services.
Review the remaining services for any suspicious or unnecessary entries. Disable any known unwanted services.
Click 'Apply' and then 'OK'. Restart the system if prompted.

title: Open Services and Review Running Services
description: Opens the Services management console (services.msc) to inspect the status, startup type, and behavior of system and third-party services.
ticket_template: Opened services.msc to review the list of running and automatic services. Checked for misconfigured, unnecessary, or suspicious services.

execution.step: Press `Win + R` to open the Run dialog.
Scroll through the list to review services by their 'Status' and 'Startup Type'.
Double-click any service to view its properties, description, dependencies, and to change its startup behavior.
Identify any unnecessary or suspicious services. Use caution when disabling services and ensure they are not critical to system stability.

title: Check and Remove Remote/Suspicious Applications
description: Manually reviews installed applications in Program Files and Apps list for any remote access or suspicious tools, and removes them if necessary.
ticket_template: Reviewed installed applications in Program Files and Apps for any remote access or unauthorized tools. Removed identified unwanted software.

execution.step: Open File Explorer and navigate to `C:\Program Files` and `C:\Program Files (x86)`.
Manually review the folders for names related to remote tools (e.g., AnyDesk, TeamViewer, Chrome Remote Desktop, UltraViewer, etc.).
Open `Settings > Apps > Installed Apps` (or `Control Panel > Programs and Features` on older systems).
Search for and uninstall any remote access or suspicious apps found in the list.
If prompted, follow the uninstaller steps and restart the system after removal.

title: Troubleshoot Printer Issues
description: Performs standard troubleshooting steps to resolve common printer issues such as offline status, driver errors, or connectivity problems.
ticket_template: Performed printer troubleshooting steps including spooler reset, driver check, and connectivity validation to resolve printing issues.

execution.step: Ensure the printer is powered on and properly connected via USB or network.
Open `Settings > Bluetooth & devices > Printers & scanners` and verify the printer appears and is not marked as 'Offline'.
Right-click the printer and select 'Run the troubleshooter' to auto-detect issues.
Restart the Print Spooler service.
execution.command: net stop spooler && net start spooler

execution.step: Open `Control Panel > Devices and Printers` to remove and re-add the printer if needed.
Check for updated printer drivers via Device Manager or the printer manufacturer's website.

title: Flush DNS Cache
description: Clears the local DNS cache to resolve name resolution issues or outdated domain entries.
ticket_template: Flushed the local DNS cache using ipconfig to resolve potential name resolution issues.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt as Administrator.
Run the following command to flush the DNS cache.
You should see a confirmation message: 'Successfully flushed the DNS Resolver Cache.'

title: Reset Winsock
description: Resets the Windows network stack (Winsock) to resolve network connectivity issues caused by corrupted configurations.
ticket_template: Performed a Winsock reset to resolve potential corruption in the Windows network stack.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt as Administrator.
Run the following command to reset Winsock.
Restart the computer to complete the reset process.

title: View ARP Cache
description: Displays the current ARP (Address Resolution Protocol) cache, showing IP-to-MAC address mappings used for local network communication.
ticket_template: Checked ARP cache using 'arp -a' to view IP-to-MAC address mappings on the local network.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt.
Run the following command to display the ARP table.
Review the listed dynamic and static IP-to-MAC address mappings for any unexpected devices or conflicts.

title: Find Router's IP Address
description: Identifies the default gateway IP address, which is typically the local IP of the router.
ticket_template: Identified the router’s IP address (default gateway) using the ipconfig command.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt.
Run the following command.
Look under the active network adapter for the line labeled 'Default Gateway'. This is your router's IP address.

title: View IP Configuration
description: Displays the current network adapter configuration including IP address, subnet mask, and default gateway.
ticket_template: Executed 'ipconfig' to review current network configuration including IP address and default gateway.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt.
Run the following command to view IP settings.
Review the output for details such as IPv4 Address, Subnet Mask, and Default Gateway under the active adapter.

title: View Full IP Configuration (ipconfig /all)
description: Displays complete network configuration details including IP address, DNS, MAC address, DHCP status, and more.
ticket_template: Ran 'ipconfig /all' to obtain detailed network information including DNS, MAC address, and DHCP configuration.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt.
Run the following command to view complete network details.
Review the output for the active adapter. Key info includes: IPv4 Address, Subnet Mask, Default Gateway, DNS Servers, MAC Address, and DHCP status.

title: Get System Information
description: Displays detailed system information including OS version, system model, BIOS, memory, and more.
ticket_template: Executed 'systeminfo' to gather detailed information about the operating system and hardware.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt.
Run the following command to retrieve system details.
Review the output for OS Name, Version, System Manufacturer, System Model, BIOS Version, and Installed Memory (RAM).

title: Get CPU Information (WMIC)
description: Retrieves processor details such as name, number of cores, and architecture using WMIC.
ticket_template: Used WMIC to retrieve CPU information including name and number of cores.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt.
Run the following command to view CPU information.
Review the output for CPU model, core count, and logical processor count.

title: Get Disk Drive Information (WMIC)
description: Retrieves physical disk drive details such as model, size, and interface type using WMIC.
ticket_template: Used WMIC to retrieve physical disk drive information including model, size, and interface type.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt.
Run the following command to view disk drive information.
Review the output for drive model, total size (in bytes), and interface type (e.g., SATA, NVMe).

title: List Installed Applications (WMIC)
description: Displays a list of installed applications and their versions using WMIC.
ticket_template: Used WMIC to retrieve a list of installed applications and their version numbers.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt as Administrator.
Run the following command to list installed programs with version info.
Review the output for a complete list of applications and their corresponding versions. Use this to identify outdated or unwanted software.

title: Get Windows OS Version (WMIC)
description: Retrieves the Windows operating system name and version using WMIC.
ticket_template: Used WMIC to retrieve the Windows operating system name and version.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt.
Run the following command to display OS name and version.
Review the output for the Windows edition (e.g., Windows 10 Pro) and its exact version number.

title: PC Optimization and Cleanup Tools
description: Guide to downloading and using optimization tools like CCleaner, SUPERAntiSpyware, and Malwarebytes to improve PC performance.
ticket_template: Performed PC optimization by downloading and running system cleanup and malware removal tools.

execution.step: Download CCleaner (Standard version) for cleaning junk files and optimizing system settings.
Download SUPERAntiSpyware (Free Edition) for detecting and removing spyware and tracking cookies.
Download Malwarebytes for scanning and removing malware and PUPs (Potentially Unwanted Programs).
Run the downloaded tools one by one to clean up the system, remove threats, and improve overall performance.

title: Install Ad Blockers for Web Browsers
description: Guide to installing Adblock Plus extensions for Chrome, Edge, Firefox, and Safari to block ads and enhance browser performance.
ticket_template: Installed Adblock Plus extensions in supported browsers to block ads and improve browsing experience.

execution.step: Install Adblock Plus for Chrome browser.
Install Adblock Plus for Microsoft Edge browser.
Install Adblock Plus for Mozilla Firefox browser.
Install Adblock Plus for Safari browser.
After installation, verify the ad blocker icon appears in the browser toolbar and test by visiting an ad-heavy website.

title: Clear Temporary Files
description: Removes temporary files from Windows temp folders to free up space and improve system performance.
ticket_template: Cleared temporary files from system and user temp folders to free up disk space and improve performance.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt as Administrator.
Delete user-level temp files.
Delete system-level temp files.
You can also manually open the temp folders via Run (`Win + R`) and entering:
Confirm deletions and skip any files currently in use.

title: Clear Prefetch Files
description: Deletes prefetch files that store data about frequently used programs to help troubleshoot performance or startup issues.
ticket_template: Cleared Windows prefetch files to troubleshoot slow boot or application performance issues.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt as Administrator.
Run the following command to delete all prefetch files.
Alternatively, open Run (Win + R) and type:
Manually select and delete all files. Skip any currently in use.

notice.content: While clearing prefetch files can help in rare troubleshooting cases, it may cause a temporary slowdown in app launches until the cache rebuilds. Not recommended as routine maintenance.

title: Run Disk Cleanup Tool
description: Frees up disk space by removing temporary files, system cache, and other unnecessary files from your system.
ticket_template: Performed Disk Cleanup to remove unnecessary system files and free up storage space.

execution.step: Open the Run dialog using `Win + R`.
Select the drive you want to clean (usually C:) and click OK.
Check the boxes for the file types you want to delete (e.g., Temporary files, Recycle Bin).
Click 'OK' and then 'Delete Files' to confirm.

notice.content: To clean up even more files, click 'Clean up system files' in the Disk Cleanup window. This option requires administrator privileges.

title: Optimize Startup Applications
description: Disables unnecessary startup programs to improve boot time and overall system responsiveness.
ticket_template: Reviewed and disabled non-essential startup applications to improve system startup performance.

execution.step: Press `Ctrl + Shift + Esc` to open Task Manager.
Go to the 'Startup' tab to view apps that launch at boot.
Review the list and check the 'Startup impact' column to identify high-impact apps.
Right-click non-essential apps and select 'Disable' to prevent them from starting with Windows.
Close Task Manager and restart the computer to apply changes.

notice.content: Disabling startup apps does not uninstall them. You can still launch them manually when needed. Focus on apps with 'High' startup impact.

title: Adjust Virtual Memory (Paging File)
description: Configures virtual memory settings to improve system performance by increasing paging file size when physical RAM is low.
ticket_template: Adjusted virtual memory settings by increasing the paging file size to improve system performance.

execution.step: Open the Start menu, search for 'Advanced system settings', and click on it.
In the 'System Properties' window, under the 'Advanced' tab, click 'Settings' in the 'Performance' section.
In 'Performance Options', go to the 'Advanced' tab and click 'Change' under 'Virtual memory'.
Uncheck 'Automatically manage paging file size for all drives'.
Select the system drive, choose 'Custom size', and set the Initial and Maximum size in MB (e.g., 1.5x to 3x of physical RAM).
Click 'Set', then click 'OK', and restart the PC to apply changes.

notice.content: Virtual memory helps prevent crashes on systems with low RAM. It's slower than physical RAM, so use it as a performance fallback, not a replacement.

title: Enable Camera Using Camera App
description: Enables a previously disabled camera by launching the Camera app or checking device settings to re-activate the device.
ticket_template: Launched the Camera app and re-enabled the previously disabled camera via app prompt or device settings.

execution.step: Open the Start menu and search for 'Camera', then launch the Camera app.
If the camera is disabled, the app will prompt you to enable it. Follow the on-screen instructions.
If the camera doesn't respond, go to `Settings > Privacy & security > Camera` and make sure camera access is enabled.
If still disabled, open Device Manager, expand 'Imaging Devices' or 'Cameras'.
Right-click the disabled camera device and choose 'Enable device'.

notice.content: Sometimes antivirus or privacy settings may block camera access. Make sure the Camera app and device drivers are allowed in system settings.

title: Get MAC Address
description: Retrieves the MAC (Media Access Control) address of the system's network adapters using the getmac command.
ticket_template: Used the getmac command to retrieve the MAC address of the device's network interfaces.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt or PowerShell.
Run the following command to list all MAC addresses and their associated transport names.

notice.content: MAC addresses are useful for identifying devices on a network or configuring static IP and security settings in routers.

title: Get Computer Hostname
description: Displays the name of the current computer as recognized by the operating system on a network.
ticket_template: Retrieved the system's hostname using the hostname command.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt or PowerShell.
Run the following command to display the computer's hostname.

notice.content: The hostname is useful for identifying the device in a network, remote desktop, or during troubleshooting sessions.

title: Export System Information to File
description: Generates a detailed summary of the system's configuration and exports it to a specified text file.
ticket_template: Ran systeminfo and exported the output to a text file for documentation or troubleshooting purposes.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt or PowerShell.
Run the command below, replacing the path as needed.

notice.content: Make sure the destination path exists and you have write permission. This can be useful for collecting system diagnostics or logs for support.

title: Run CHKDSK Scan
description: Checks the file system and file system metadata of a drive for logical and physical errors. Can also fix found issues when run with parameters.
ticket_template: Ran CHKDSK to scan the drive for file system errors and bad sectors.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt as Administrator.
Run the CHKDSK scan on the desired drive (example below is for C:).
If the drive is in use, you may be prompted to schedule the scan on the next restart. Type 'Y' and press Enter.

notice.content: Running CHKDSK with `/f /r` may take a long time and requires a restart if scanning the system drive. Make sure to save all work before proceeding.

title: Kill Process by Name
description: Forcefully terminates a running process by specifying its executable name.
ticket_template: Forcefully terminated a process by its executable name to stop unresponsive or malicious activity.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt or PowerShell as Administrator.
Run the following command, replacing `program.exe` with the exact process name.

notice.content: Force-killing processes may cause unsaved data loss. Only terminate processes you are sure about.

title: List Running Processes
description: Displays a list of all currently running processes along with their Process ID (PID) and memory usage.
ticket_template: Retrieved a list of currently running processes for troubleshooting purposes.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt or PowerShell.
Run the following command to display all running processes.

notice.content: You can use `tasklist /v` for more detailed output, including window titles and status.

title: Reset TCP/IP Stack
description: Resets the TCP/IP stack to its default configuration, which can help resolve network connectivity issues.
ticket_template: Reset the TCP/IP stack to default settings to resolve possible network configuration issues.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt as Administrator.
Run the following command to reset TCP/IP settings.
Restart the computer to apply the changes.

notice.content: This will reset all custom TCP/IP settings. You may need to reconfigure your network or VPN settings afterward.

title: Disable Hibernation
description: Turns off the hibernation feature, which can free up disk space by removing the hiberfil.sys file.
ticket_template: Disabled Windows hibernation to free up disk space and prevent system from entering hibernation mode.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt as Administrator.
Run the following command to disable hibernation.

notice.content: Disabling hibernation will remove the hiberfil.sys file and disable Fast Startup. To re-enable, run `powercfg /h on`.

title: Defragment and Optimize Drive
description: Optimizes and defragments the specified drive to improve performance and consolidate fragmented files.
ticket_template: Ran disk defragmentation and optimization on the C: drive to improve performance.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt as Administrator.
Run the defrag and optimization command for the C: drive.

notice.content: The `/O` parameter performs optimization suitable for the media type, including defragmentation on HDDs and retrim on SSDs.

title: Force Reboot
description: Immediately restarts the computer without any warning and without allowing applications to save their data. '/r' is for reboot, '/f' is for force, and '/t 0' sets the time delay to zero seconds.
ticket_template: Executed the 'shutdown /r /f /t 0' command to immediately restart the computer.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt.
Run the command to immediately restart the computer.

notice.content: This command will force close all running applications without saving any work. Use with caution to prevent data loss.

title: Force Shutdown
description: Immediately shuts down the computer without any warning and without allowing applications to save their data. '/s' is for shutdown, '/f' is for force, and '/t 0' sets the time delay to zero seconds.
ticket_template: Executed the 'shutdown /s /f /t 0' command to immediately shut down the computer.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt.
Run the command to immediately shut down the computer.

notice.content: This command will force close all running applications without saving any work. Use with caution to prevent data loss.

title: Display System Information
description: Displays detailed configuration information about the local computer's operating system, hardware, and network settings.
ticket_template: Used the 'systeminfo' command to gather detailed information about the system, including OS version and hotfix data.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt.
Run the command to display system information. The process may take a moment to gather all the data.

notice.content: You can redirect the output to a text file for easy sharing or reference by using the command 'systeminfo > system_info.txt'.

title: Remove File Attributes
description: Removes the hidden, system, and read-only attributes from a specified file or folder, making it visible and modifiable.
ticket_template: Used 'attrib -h -s -r [filename]' to remove the hidden, system, and read-only attributes from a file.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt.
Navigate to the directory where the file is located. Run the command, replacing 'filename' with the actual file name.

notice.content: To perform this action on all files in a directory and its subdirectories, you can use the '/s' and '/d' switches: 'attrib -h -s -r *.* /s /d'. Be careful when removing these attributes from system files.

title: Show Network Connections and Listening Ports
description: Displays all active TCP connections, listening ports, and the Process ID (PID) associated with each connection or port.
ticket_template: Ran 'netstat -ano' to troubleshoot network connections and identify the PID of a process using a specific port.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt.
Run the command to display network statistics with PIDs.
The output will show the Protocol, Local Address, Foreign Address, State, and PID. You can then use the PID with Task Manager or 'tasklist' to identify the process.

notice.content: The 'o' parameter is crucial as it displays the PID, allowing you to link a network connection to a specific process. You can use 'tasklist /svc /fi "PID eq [PID_number]"' to find the service associated with the PID.

title: Change User Password
description: Changes the password for a specified user account. The asterisk (*) prompts for a new password without displaying it on the screen.
ticket_template: Used the 'net user [username] *' command to change the password for the '[username]' account.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt as Administrator.
Run the command, replacing 'username' with the actual user account name. You will be prompted to enter and confirm a new password.

notice.content: This command requires administrative privileges. Replacing 'username' with an actual user account name will change their password. This cannot be undone.

title: List User Accounts
description: Displays a list of all user accounts on the local computer.
ticket_template: Used the 'net user' command to list all user accounts on the system.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt.
Run the command to display a list of user accounts.

notice.content: To get detailed information about a specific user, use the command 'net user [username]'.

title: Securely Delete Free Space
description: Securely overwrites and deletes unused free space on a specified drive to prevent recovery of previously deleted files.
ticket_template: Ran the cipher /w:C command to securely wipe free space on the C: drive.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt.
Run the cipher command to wipe free space on the C: drive. This process can take a long time.

notice.content: This command can take a very long time to complete, depending on the amount of free space on the drive. It will not delete or alter any existing files.

title: Generate Battery Report
description: Creates a detailed battery usage and health report, saved as an HTML file on your system.
ticket_template: Generated a detailed battery report to review battery health and usage history.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt or PowerShell as Administrator.
Run the following command to generate a battery report.
The report will be saved as `battery-report.html` in the current user directory. Open it in a web browser to view details.

notice.content: The battery report provides information about battery capacity, recent usage, and charge cycles. Useful for diagnosing battery performance issues.

title: Generate Energy Efficiency Report
description: Analyzes the system for common energy efficiency and battery-related issues, saving the results in an HTML file.
ticket_template: Generated an energy efficiency report to analyze system power-related issues and optimization opportunities.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt or PowerShell as Administrator.
Run the following command to analyze energy efficiency.
After 60 seconds, an HTML report named `energy-report.html` will be created in the current user directory. Open it in a web browser to review the findings.

notice.content: The report highlights issues like device drivers preventing sleep, inefficient power settings, and other energy-related warnings.

title: Generate Sleep Study Report
description: Creates a detailed report of system sleep states and power usage during standby, saved as an HTML file.
ticket_template: Generated a Sleep Study report to analyze system power consumption and behavior during standby.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt or PowerShell as Administrator.
Run the following command to generate a Sleep Study report.
The report will be saved as `sleepstudy-report.html` in the current user directory. Open it in a web browser to view details.

notice.content: Sleep Study is only available on systems that support Modern Standby. It helps identify apps, devices, or drivers that drain power during sleep.

title: Open Startup Folder
description: Opens the Startup folder where you can add or remove program shortcuts that run automatically when Windows starts.
ticket_template: Accessed the Startup folder to review and manage programs that launch automatically at Windows startup.

execution.step: Open the Run dialog by pressing `Win + R`.
Type the following command and press Enter to open the Startup folder.

notice.content: Adding shortcuts here will make programs start automatically with Windows. Removing them will stop automatic startup for that program.

title: Open Applications Folder
description: Opens the Applications folder, which displays all installed apps and programs in one place for management or shortcut creation.
ticket_template: Accessed the Applications folder to review or manage installed apps and programs.

execution.step: Open the Run dialog by pressing `Win + R`.
Type the following command and press Enter to open the Applications folder.

notice.content: From this folder, you can create shortcuts, pin apps to Start or Taskbar, or quickly launch installed applications.

title: Open SendTo Folder
description: Opens the SendTo folder, which controls the options shown in the 'Send to' menu when right-clicking files or folders.
ticket_template: Accessed the SendTo folder to review or customize the shortcuts available in the right-click 'Send to' menu.

execution.step: Open the Run dialog by pressing `Win + R`.
Type the following command and press Enter to open the SendTo folder.

notice.content: You can add or remove shortcuts here to customize the 'Send to' menu, such as sending files directly to specific folders, apps, or drives.

title: Run Microsoft Malicious Software Removal Tool
description: Launches the Microsoft Malicious Software Removal Tool (MRT) to scan and remove specific prevalent malware from Windows systems.
ticket_template: Ran Microsoft Malicious Software Removal Tool (MRT) to check for and remove malicious software.

execution.step: Open the Run dialog by pressing `Win + R`.
Type the following command and press Enter to launch the Malicious Software Removal Tool.
Follow the on-screen instructions to perform a Quick, Full, or Customized scan.

notice.content: MRT is updated monthly via Windows Update. It is not a replacement for real-time antivirus software but can help remove common malware infections.

title: Show Saved Wi-Fi Profiles
description: Lists all saved wireless network profiles stored on the computer, including their names (SSIDs).
ticket_template: Displayed all saved Wi-Fi profiles on the system for review or troubleshooting connectivity issues.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt or PowerShell.
Run the following command to list all saved Wi-Fi profiles.

notice.content: You can view details of a specific Wi-Fi profile using `netsh wlan show profile name="ProfileName" key=clear` to reveal its saved password and settings.

title: Delete Saved Wi-Fi Profile
description: Removes a saved wireless network profile from the computer, which can help fix connectivity issues or reset Wi-Fi settings for that network.
ticket_template: Deleted a saved Wi-Fi profile to reset its settings or resolve connectivity problems.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt or PowerShell.
Run the following command, replacing `ProfileName` with the actual Wi-Fi name (SSID).

notice.content: Deleting a Wi-Fi profile removes its saved password and settings. The network will need to be reconnected manually afterward.

title: Delete All Saved Wi-Fi Profiles
description: Removes all saved wireless network profiles from the computer, clearing all stored SSIDs and passwords.
ticket_template: Cleared all saved Wi-Fi profiles from the system to reset wireless network configurations.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt or PowerShell.
Run the following command to delete all saved Wi-Fi profiles from all interfaces.
execution.command: netsh wlan delete profile name=* i=*

notice.content: This will remove **all** saved Wi-Fi networks and passwords. You’ll need to reconnect manually to each network afterward.

title: Run Windows Defender Offline Scan
description: Initiates an offline scan using Microsoft Defender to detect and remove persistent or hard-to-remove malware outside the normal Windows environment.
ticket_template: Ran a Windows Defender Offline Scan to detect and remove deeply embedded or persistent malware.

execution.step: Open PowerShell as Administrator.
Run the following command to initiate a Windows Defender Offline Scan.
The system will restart automatically and perform the offline scan before booting back into Windows.

notice.content: The computer will restart immediately after this command. Save all work before proceeding. The scan runs outside of Windows and may take several minutes.

title: Run Windows Defender Quick Scan
description: Performs a quick scan using Microsoft Defender to check common malware locations such as startup folders, system memory, and registry entries.
ticket_template: Performed a Windows Defender Quick Scan to check for active threats in common system areas.

execution.step: Open PowerShell as Administrator.
Run the following command to start a Windows Defender Quick Scan.
Wait for the scan to complete. Results will be displayed once the process finishes.

notice.content: Quick Scan checks areas where threats are most likely to be found. For a deeper check, use `Start-MpScan -ScanType FullScan`.

title: Check and Upgrade Installed Apps with Winget
description: Lists available updates for installed applications and allows upgrading them using the Windows Package Manager (Winget).
ticket_template: Checked and upgraded installed applications using Winget to ensure all software is up to date.

execution.step: Open Command Prompt or PowerShell as Administrator.
Run the following command to view available application updates.
To upgrade all apps automatically, run the following command.

notice.content: Winget simplifies software maintenance by automatically checking for updates. Some apps may require a restart or manual confirmation during upgrade.

title: Search and Install an App with Winget
description: Uses the Windows Package Manager (Winget) to search for and install specific applications from the official repositories.
ticket_template: Searched and installed a specific application using the Windows Package Manager (Winget).

execution.step: Open Command Prompt or PowerShell as Administrator.
Run the following command to search for the desired application by name.
Once found, run the following command to install the application.

notice.content: Winget installs applications from trusted sources. Some installations may prompt for confirmation or require a system restart.

title: Uninstall an App with Winget
description: Removes an installed application from Windows using the Windows Package Manager (Winget).
ticket_template: Uninstalled an application using the Windows Package Manager (Winget).

execution.step: Open Command Prompt or PowerShell as Administrator.
Run the following command, replacing `appname` with the actual name of the application to uninstall.
Confirm the uninstallation if prompted and wait for the process to complete.

notice.content: Winget simplifies app removal, but some applications may leave residual files or settings. For a complete cleanup, check for leftover folders in Program Files or AppData.

title: Install PowerShell via Winget
description: Installs the latest version of Microsoft PowerShell from the official Winget repository.
ticket_template: Installed or updated Microsoft PowerShell using the Windows Package Manager (Winget).

execution.step: Open Command Prompt or PowerShell as Administrator.
Run the following command to install the latest version of PowerShell.
After installation, search for 'PowerShell' in the Start Menu to open the updated version.

notice.content: If PowerShell is already installed, this command will update it to the latest available version. A system restart may be required to complete the setup.

title: Remove Hidden Remote Access Tools (ConnectWise or ScreenConnect)
description: Removes malicious or hidden remote connection clients that cannot be uninstalled normally from Programs and Features or found in Program Files.
ticket_template: User reported unauthorized remote access or hidden remote tool installed. Performed manual cleanup and service removal.

execution.step: Open the Windows Services Manager.
execution.command: Press Windows + R → type services.msc → press Enter.

execution.step: Locate the malicious service.
execution.command: Look for a service named 'ConnectWise Control Client' or 'ScreenConnect Client' (it may include random letters/numbers).

execution.step: Stop the service.
execution.command: Right-click the identified service → click Stop.

execution.step: Open an elevated Command Prompt.
execution.command: Search for 'cmd', right-click Command Prompt, and select 'Run as administrator'.

execution.step: Delete the service.
execution.command: sc delete "ConnectWise Control Client (xxxxxxxx)" or sc delete "ScreenConnect Client (xxxxxxxx)"

execution.step: Verify service removal.
execution.command: Reopen services.msc and confirm the service no longer appears in the list.

notice.content: Make sure to verify with the user before deleting any service. Malicious remote tools often disguise themselves with random names—double-check the service path and description before removal.
